Award.AwardTitle: Teaming Engineering And Mathematics Students: Part 2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: "Teaming Engineering and Mathematics Students: Part 2 (TEAMS2)" is awarding scholarships to academically talented and financially needy students and continues to support these scholars through a variety of structures and programs. TEAMS2 is a continuation of a successful S-STEM program (TEAMS) that has provided scholarships to 58 students: 30% of these scholars are women, 31% are Hispanic, and 90% are still in the program (or have graduated and are currently working in a STEM industry). TEAMS2 builds on the successes of TEAMS while also adding content to the program based on an external evaluation and assessment of current and past scholars. Students from underrepresented groups are being especially targeted for this support in a region that is primarily rural and where most students are first-generation. Students are being targeted for participation in three departments: mechanical engineering, civil engineering and mathematics. The TEAMS2 project is well-integrated with a STEP program on campus and builds upon the natural cohort relationship that occurs among engineering and mathematics students within their twenty-four credit hours of required mathematics instruction. Students are being supported by project personnel who have special expertise in five areas: mentoring, academic counseling, career counseling, research/internships, and professional interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF’s support has had a profound impact on the development and growth of WTAMU’s engineering programs. Since 2003 when the program was establish, in part with support from NSF, enrollment has grown from five white male students to a population of 713 students that is even more diverse than the overall institution. Subsequent NSF support also facilitated the addition of programs in civil, environmental, and electrical engineering. 

Scholarships for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Scholarship (S-STEM)—(DUE 0728611; $570,000, 2007-2011, E.Hunt, PI)and (DUE 1060242; $599,996, 2010-2015, E.Hunt, PI). These two S-STEM awards for the WTAMU Teaming Engineering and Mathematics Students Parts 1 and 2 provided 203 scholarships to undergraduate engineering and mathematics majors from Fall 2007 through Spring 2017. Over half of the TEAMS Scholars were first-generation students.

Among the many successes of the TEAMS program, we are particularly proud of our ability to recruit, retain, and graduate women and minority students in engineering and mathematics. Nationwide, less than 18% of engineering students are women, and less than 13% are minority (N. C. f. S. a. E. S. National Science Foundation, 2015).The underrepresented students in the TEAMS program reflect the distribution of these groups in our engineering programs, with approximately 31% of scholarships recipients going to women and approximately 31% to minority students. The TEAMS program has also been enormously successful in helping students attain the goal of continuing in a STEM career. Since 2008, 90% of TEAMS participants are still in the program or have graduated and are continuing STEM education or are currently working in a STEM field. Although S-STEM is designed to support academically promising students and therefore includes a cohort that is already more likely to graduate than the general population of undergraduate STEM students, a 90% retention/graduation-to-STEM-career rate is exceptional in any area, but particularly so in engineering and mathematics, which tend to underperform relative to other STEM fields.

West Texas Evaluation and Research (WTER) conducted the TEAMS evaluation through focus groups, surveys, and personal interviews with the TEAMS scholars. Each year, the scholars reported that, other than their scholarship, the mentoring program was the most helpful component of the TEAMS program for helping them succeed in engineering or mathematics. We also learned that the mentoring program has evolved informally to include a version of peer-led team learning (PLTL), and scholars who reported participating in these activities reported they were more comfortable approaching their peers for help in a class rather than students from the tutoring center on campus or the faculty member. They also said that the mentoring program helped them to establish relationships in engineering and mathematics which was a significant factor in their decision to continue the degree program when things got tough.
